metadata.case_name: Steward Hogg Market & Anr. v. State

facts.text: On June 1, 1960 a Food Inspector of the Corporation of Calcutta visited the shop of the appellants. At that time Abdul Razzak was in charge.
He took samples of Comela Brand condensed milk from the shop, one of which was sent to the Public Analyst.
Upon analysis, the milk fat content of the condensed milk was found to be 3.4% which did not conform to the prescribed standard of at least 9% fat.
A complaint was lodged against the firm and five other persons, including Abdul Razzak, before the Municipal Magistrate.
Mohd. Yasin did not appear but was given up as not mentally fit.
Other accused pleaded not guilty and were acquitted by the Magistrate.
High Court allowed appeal under s.417 CrPC only against appellants and dismissed against others, dated May 14, 1963.
Tins of condensed milk purchased by firm on May 3, 1960 from Messrs S. Choudhury Brothers under document Ex. A.
Firm demanded warranty but not furnished written; traders said certificate and warranty on each tin.
Tins were in the same condition as purchased; no reason to believe alteration in nature, substance or quality.
Attempt to secure appearance of S. Choudhury failed as he could not be traced.

legal_issues.text: Whether the defence under s.19(2) of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 is available to the appellants, particularly regarding whether the labels on the tins or cash memo constituted a written warranty in the prescribed form.
Whether the condensed milk stored by appellants was adulterated under s.2(i) as fat content was below prescribed standard.

petitioner_arguments.text: Labels on tins satisfy requirements of proviso to Rule 12-A as they state 'Comela-Full Cream sweetened condensed milk' and describe contents from healthy cows milk.
Cash memo also satisfies conditions; words 'Full Cream' imply compliance with standards.

respondent_arguments.text: No written warranty in prescribed form obtained; labels do not certify that food is same in nature, substance and quality as demanded.

court_reasoning.text: Condensed milk was adulterated as fat content 3.4% below 9% prescribed in A.11.07 Appendix B; thus breach of s.16(1)(a)(i).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Article falls below prescribed standard, deemed adulterated.

court_reasoning.text: Defence under s.19(2) requires purchase with written warranty in prescribed form or equivalent on label/cash memo certifying same nature, substance, quality; appellants failed to prove this.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Labels describe but do not warrant compliance; 'Full Cream' undefined and insufficient without quantities.

court_reasoning.text: Label not in prescribed form under r.42-B; cash memo only lists '1 C.C. Comela Milk' without warranty.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No certification that it meets standards demanded.

court_reasoning.text: Bachawat J.: Defence fails as no written warranty; label gives description but not warranty certifying same nature, substance, quality.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Had warranty on label been present, defence would succeed.

holdings.text: Defence under s.19(2) not available without proper written warranty in prescribed form or equivalent certification on label/cash memo.
Condensed milk with fat below 9% is adulterated; storing/selling violates s.16(1)(a)(i).

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines adulteration, prescribes punishment for storing/selling adulterated food, provides defence for vendors with warranty.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Food Adulteration Rules, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Prescribes standards for condensed milk (31% milk solids, 9% fat); form and requirements for warranty.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upheld High Court's order setting aside acquittal and convicting appellants under s.16(1)(a)(i) of Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, sentenced each to fine of Rs. 2,000.

key_quotes.text: "A vendor shall not be deemed to have committed an offence if he proves... that the article of food was purchased by him as the same in nature, substance and quality as that demanded by the purchaser and with a written warranty..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.19(2) defining conditions for vendor defence.

key_quotes.text: "The label contains no warranty of the kind referred to in the proviso."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects appellants' reliance on tin labels as warranty.

key_quotes.text: "Had there been such a written warranty on the label, the appellants would have established the defence."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Bachawat J. clarifies what would have succeeded the defence.
